dict.string: Sherlock saw the man with binoculars. -- structurally ambiguous, just like the "unlockable lock" last time
syntax is the study of sentence formation and structure. -- attempt to make generalizations about how words combine.
an infinite number of sentences
memorizing sentences isn't how we understand and use language
there are predictable patterns
why abstract generalization?
Syntax: what is syntax and why it needs abstract generalization
basically, "if it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's probably a duck."
if it acts like a noun (verb, adjective, preposition…) then it probably is a noun(verb, adjective, preposition…)
some morphological affixes can only attach to words of certain grammatical category.
we can say smile-ed and talk-ed but not *desk-ed or *toward-ed

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 we can say \b smile-ed \b0 and \b talk-ed \b0 but not * \b desk-ed \b0 or \b *toward-ed}
morphological criteria
only certain kinds of words can be put in syntactic frames and form grammatical sentences.
we can say [the man left] but not *[the red left] or *[the talk left]

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 we can say [the \b man \b0 left] but not *[the \b red \b0 left] or *[the \b talk \b0 left]}
different languages have different distributional criteria
syntactic criteria
the best way is to use distributional criteria
how does a noun/verb/adjective/preposition/etc. act?
how to identify grammatical categories:
description of them
if a word can occur with the plural morphemes it's probably a noun
if a word cannot occur with the plural morpheme, it might not be a noun
but note some verbs like "runs"…
recall that there is one inflectional affix that attaches to nouns in English: the plural morpheme -s.
entertainment, happiness, purity, democratization, anarchist, greenery, employee, friendship, millionaire, celbacy, piglet, gosling, falsehood, minimalism, running.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 entertain \b ment \b0 , happi \b ness \b0 , pur \b ity \b0 , democratiz \b ation \b0 , anarch \b ist \b0 , green \b ery \b0 , employ \b ee \b0 , friend \b ship \b0 , million \b aire \b0 , celb \b acy, \b0 pig \b let \b0 , gos \b ling \b0 , false \b hood \b0 , minimal \b ism \b0 , runn \b ing \b0 .}
there are also several derivational affixes that attach to other grammatical categories and can result in nouns.
say we have independent evidence for two other categories: verbs and determiners (like the, that, all). if a word can "fit" between a determiner and a verb, it's a noun. [DET ____ VERB]
other positions nouns can occur: after adjectives, after prepositions
common nouns: can occur with determiners before them and have a plural form, like cat, the cat, cats, the cats
proper nouns: typically don't occur wit determiners before them in English or have plural forms, like Torontos, the Derek
pronouns: don't occur with determiners in English or the plural -s morpheme (though they do have plural form)
concrete nouns: refer to something in the real world while abstract nouns don't.
count nouns: can be pluralized and mass nouns can't be
(not for all nouns!) sub-categories of nouns

four inflectional affixes: 3rd person, singular agreement marker -s, the past tense marker -ed, the progressive aspect marker -ing, the perfect marker -en. some verbs in english have irregular morphology.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 four \b inflectional affixes \b0 : 3rd person, singular agreement marker \b -s \b0 , the past tense marker \b -ed \b0 , the progressive aspect marker \b -ing \b0 , the perfect marker \b -en \b0 . some verbs in english have irregular morphology.}
derivational affixes: originate, hospitalize, falsify

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\b\fs24 \cf2 derivational affixes: \b0 origin \b ate, \b0 hospital \b ize \b0 , fals \b ify}
[(DET) NOUN ___]
other positions verbs can occur: after or before adverbs
intransitive verbs: don't occur with nouns after them. e.g Doug laughed. but *Doug laughed Andy.
transitive verbs: require one noun after them, strictly transitive verbs are rare in English.
Ditransitive verbs: require two nouns after them (direct and indirect)
main verbs: can be the only verb in a sentence. e.g. Have lexical content. John has left, Bill will sing, Sam was sitting.
auxiliary verbs: can never be the only verb in a sentence
sub-categories of verbs
two inflectional affixes: -er and -est
derivational affixes: -ing, -ive, -al, -ate, -ish, -some, -y, -(i)an, -ful, -ly, -ous
[DET ___ NOUN]
derivational suffix: -ly
[DET NOUN VERB ___]
articles: the, a, an
demonstratives: this, that, these, those
quantifiers: all, every, some, most, many, no, any…
numerals: one, two, three, …
possessive pronouns: my, your, his, her, our, …
some wh-words: whose, which
determiners are a closed class
[ ___ (ADJ) NOUN ]
only five complementizers: that, if, whether, for, and a "null" complementizer
[ NOUN VERB ___ NOUN VERB]
morphological criteria: and, or, but, either, neither, nor are all conjunctions.
syntactic criteria: [NOUN + NOUN] [VERB + VERB] [ ADJ + ADJ]
indicate something about location or paths
to, from, under, over, with, by, at, above, before, after, through, near, on, off, for, in, into, during, across…
morphological criteria: closed class like determiners, complementizers, and conjunctions but there are about 70 of them in English.
syntactic criteria: prepositions can fit into the following frame, subject to an appropriate verb: [DET NOUN VERB DET NOUN ___ DET NOUN]
grammatical categories in syntax
using morphology and syntactic templates to identify them

we've been using frames (or templates) for our distributional tests of grammatical category. e.g. [DET NOUN VERB]. although templates are suitable for these tests, they are not efficient way to capture the power of the syntactic component of human language.
a finite set of procedures that generate the infinitely-possible grammatical sentences of a language.
generative rules produce syntactic trees.
one rule can get us an infinite number of sentences
A recursive rule: it can be applied to its own output over and over, resulting in a theoretically-possible infinite loop. e.g.: Alice knows Lewis said you thought N V…
generative rules (Phrase Structure Rules)

Noam Chomsky proposed that syntax is generative and recursive: generative in the sense that it generates only the grammatical sentences of a language and none of the ungrammatical sentences. recursive in the sense that some elements of the structure can reproduce themselves.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 Noam Chomsky proposed that syntax is \b generative \b0 and \b recursive \b0 : \b generative \b0 in the sense that it generates only the grammatical sentences of a language and none of the ungrammatical sentences. \b recursive \b0 in the sense that some elements of the structure can reproduce themselves.}

language has a property called recursion: we are able to embedded sentences within other sentences. if we can take a [N V] sentence on the end of another [N V] sentence, theoretically, we could do this forever.
1. syntax is infinite
does not work for 'the fat cat can eat now -> fat the cat can eat now?"
linear rule: move the second word to the beginning of the sentence
hierarchical rule works!
e.g. we can eat now -> can we eat now?
the rules we've seen have been relatively flat giving a linear order to most of our structures, but syntax is not linear -- it is hierarchically organized and composed of parts we call constituents.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1187\cocoasubrtf400 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 the rules we've seen have been relatively \b flat \b0 giving a \b linear \b0 order to most of our structures, but syntax is not linear -- it is \b hierarchically organized \b0 and composed of parts we call \b constituents.}
we cannot come up with a rule for English question formation by only referring to linear order.
NP: Noun Phrase, the bolded groups of words surrounded by brackets all form a type of constituent called NP.
[we] can eat now
[the fat cat] can eat now
[the fat cat who is sitting next to me] can eat now

the hierarchical approach makes reference to these groups. we call them constituents, which are internal syntactic structure; groups of words functioning as a unit. represented between square brackets []
there are also other phrases as constituents:
2. syntax is hierarchical (composed of constituent parts)
S -> NP VP
PP -> P NP
the rules we need for this tree:
That very small dog on the porch quietly slept.

the meaning of a string of words is determined by its component parts and their relations to one another. in other words, the order which you combine constituents hierarchically is crucial to the meaning of the sentence.
3. syntax is compositional
three core properties of human language syntax
generative rules and syntactic structure
Syntax
